content.description:
A fun ridge that leaves lots to the imagination.  There is no particular way to go, the ridge is broad and split by several gullies and various degrees of lithified (generous term) shit (hyperbole); much of which is able to be enjoyed. From lower twin lake (the 3rd lake on the way in), track along its west bank keeping an eye for the best line through the trees and bush to the tarn below the SE cirque, which contains some serious route potential.  From the tarn, cruise along meadowy ridges and talus to gain the East Ridge proper.  From here just piece your way up the mountain, generally adhere to the ridge for steeper and better petra, though deviations are inevitable.  Beware the summit cornice, should you pop through a speed descent of the big NE face shall determine thee- emphasis on big face. 2 options for down 1) North ridge, long and tedious with the benefit of getting you back to the Arnica Trail.  Not entirely sure of the viability of this option.   2)Western slopes (cairns?) down to a creek emerging from the jumble.   There is a faint trail along its east bank through mucho deadfall which will lead to the highway and 2km back to loop completion. Borderlands of Kootenay and Banff parks, just east of Mt. Stanley.
Walk the Arnica Lake trail to upper twin lake (NE face access) and lower twin lake for the east ridge.  Moderately frustrating amount of up-down. light rack

climbs.name: Eye of the Storm
climbs.fa: October 2019, Maarten van Haeren and Ethan Berman

content.description:
Hike to Upper Twin Lake, following hiking trails from 93S or Castle Junction (both 2:30-3:00 hrs). Hike N shore of the lake and approach route (1:00-1:30 hours from lake). P1: WI3 70m: Climb easy ice to below steep pillar
P2: WI5 M6, 70m: Climb steep ice for 30m, pull a brief overhang (could be pure ice in good year) and continue up an aesthetic ice goulette, stretching the rope for a sheltered belay.
P3-5: WI3+ snow, 180m: Continue up snow and ice till below the next long ice drip (and a deep chimney on the right)
P6: WI3 M5, 70m: Climb a slanting groove (sustained at grade) on the R side of the ice, gaining the ice flow. Belay here or continue to the end of the ice.
P7: M5, 60m: The one scrappy pitch. From the end of the ice, follow chimney on right. Step onto a ridge notch, then step back left to continue to another ridge (good ledge/ridge belay). The upper corner should be visible from the belay.
P8: M5, 50m: Traverse right from belay and start up the striking quartzite corner. Belay on obvious ledge on right (save a 0.4 cam for anchor).
P9: M6, 60m: Continue up the corner on more great climbing and gear, through a small overlap. Exit corner, move up and R to small ledge and views of the NE face proper.
P10: M4 70m: Step right and continue up the blunt ridge.
P11: M5 70m: Follow a snow/ice gully on right to east ridge of Storm mountain. Info for this route provided with permission by Ethan Berman. You can read his full write up about the route on his website. As for east ridge of Storm Mountain. From top out, scramble briefly north and make one 30m rappel (slung block). Walk towards lower Twin Lake (traverse high skiers left), then meet lake at north end. Cams to #3, hexes, pins (two angles, 4 KBs, 3-4 beaks), 10 screws (short and long), 12-14 draws.
Two 70m ropes.
Another classy chossies peak with a somewhat short approach and a variety of routes including 5th realm of hell (wrath for those curious) slogging and 5.9 A2 curiosities and some betwixt.
